prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ebonite feed heat‑set". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Ebonite Feed Heat-Set

The ebonite feed heat-set was glibbering at the brink,
Its whorl-warped jaws a-whicker, with snithering snap and clink;
Beware the plasmic sprattle, the sproink of molten ink—
For grobble in the shiver-core, the timbrel thorns will sink.

He took a vorpal glimble-stave of tempered quartz and tin,
With click-clock coils of cinder-thread he lashed the zither-pin;
He slathered flux of friggle-oil and sang the warding hymn,
Then spindled spry the gyro-cage to cage the creeping grim.

Through slubber-fraught meridian he trudged with clanking tread,
Past slurp and brattle of the broil where gloam-green vapours bled;
The ebonite feed heat-set rose, its carapace deep-red,
And razzled razors of its breath clanged shiver-shards of dread.

One!—Two!—the glimble-stave came down in whirling gyve and gyre,
It snicker-snacked through carbuncled plates, it lopped the snarling spire;
The flux went hiss, the hymn went hush, the gloam-green fumes retired—
He left it twitching, gimbal-broke, its molten core expired.

He galumphed back through slubber-gloam, his vorpal trophy high;
The timbrel thorns unclenched their grip, the broil began to dry;
“O frabjous feat!” the elders cried, “our feed-ways purged of sty!”
He chortled in his triumph, beneath the copper sky.

The ebonite feed heat-set was glibbering at the brink,
Its whorl-warped jaws a-whicker, with snithering snap and clink;
Beware the plasmic sprattle, the sproink of molten ink—
For grobble in the shiver-core, the timbrel thorns will sink.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Hollowgrinder’s Hymn

The hollowgrind on O1 blade did gleam and glint and glide,  
Its whiffle-edge a-whirl beneath the waning wabe;  
Beware the burr that whispers, the wire that will not bide,  
For steel can snicker-snack and turn the bravest knave.  

He took the strop of camphor’d hide, the rouge of ruddy glede,  
He honed the bevel’s belly with a hush of hushling breath;  
He flexed the spine, he tested keen, he prayed the gods of speed,  
Then stepped into the twilight where the shadows sip of death.  

The Hollowgrinder, snorfling, came with talons tungsten-tipped,  
Its eye a carbide crater, its breath a rasping roar;  
It ground the air to silver dust, it ground the dark and dipped  
The moon in molten metal till the night was metal’s floor.  

One slash! The O1 sang a song of slicing, silver-slick,  
A zing! a cling! a ringing thing that split the grinding gloom;  
The Hollowgrinder shivered, its gears began to tick,  
Then toppled, twirled, and tinkled like a broken bit of broom.  

He bore the blade back homeward through the hush of hollow night,  
Its edge a quiet quiver, its spine a steady song;  
The hollowgrind on O1 blade still gleams and glints in light—  
Beware the burr that whispers, the wire that will not bide for long.

info.topic: hollow grind on an O1 blade

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Falsiflitter's Foliole

In forgespark where swindlebloom is wrought,  
Where smoldergilt ignites the wyverflame,  
A whifflewight unreeled its shadow-scrawl,  
‘Ware! blistervine beguiles the scroll of name.  

From brassflick clatters rang the amber-tongs,  
Its leafbelch forged of brindlebronze insight;  
But clipperclocks caught snaggleteeth in the runes  
And clanged the foliole of darkish light.  

“O burblebard, beware the Falsiflitter!  
Its giltgrin serpentines like sneer of quill!  
Come bracket-bladed scritcher of true-silver—  
Unscroll its venom leaf and freeze the thrill!”  

He trussled through the dross of blisterday;  
His hearthlamp fizzled in the flouncing flow.  
Behind him hopped the jottlewhelp—red-cray,  
Its inkpad paws poised firm to stamp the foe.  

Deep now among the rustlings of deadled dew,  
The Falsiflitter leaf-flicked flame to dread:  
Its motto—bright, insidious, askew—  
Spelled promises the unsuspecting read.  

With blinter blade he smote the ficklefoil—  
Shrill sizzlept!—sliced the serpent-scroll in half;  
The javellight jarred, the cozened ember spoil  
Fell moultergold upon the stone altar’s laugh.  

Home, hearth again aglow with his return,  
He cast the burnting scrap to scutfire's bowl.  
So mind the trade where forgerfires churn:  
‘Ware smoldergilt, O clink of slandered soul!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiln witness cone bend". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Conefernillikiln  
When firedrakes in kilnfern’s cusp did pyzzle, wickly warping,  
And witness-cones beneath the blazen rack went slendid curling,  
O glowbraid tongues would spitter-snap at timbertils of clay—  
Beware the Bendwatcher, child, whose glare makes furnaces obey!  

He flanged his steelstrom whiskers, sniffed the sulphur-saffron air,  
Took tongs of gosslank iron, hung caution on the ware;  
He annealed amber ursyrups for brittle brickish banes,  
And chilled the kiln-crypt silence with porcelainy refrains.  

In smokestack’s blackwhorled throat the embered cyclone riz—  
A doorflump slammed! the kilnwolf growled, a white-hot vitriose fizz.  
Its snout of liquid obsid gleamed, its paws of moltslag clanged;  
With every gnash, flaw-cracks laughed, and poreclots sprang and sprang.  

One!… Two!… the lenswink third— bendcone buckled, amber purled—  
He gripped the spiral testareel and into furnace hurled.  
Zzzthrup! the coreflash vortex drank the mortal measured flee,  
The Bendwatcher barked, the angle snapped cone to a gleeful “gree.”  

Home he rambled, kilnlight fading, bearing bending cone-o-merk,  
Past charred kilns and keening kilns and kilns that only lurk.  
He slammed the wheelbuck door, hung trophies in the hazen beam—  
“By cone-lit witness conquered flame; by biscuit dream I dream.”  

When firedrakes in kilnfern’s cusp still pyzzle, wickly warping,  
And witness-cones beneath the blazen rack keep slendid curling—  
Sing soft the soul of kiln’s gray throat, hold caution close and true;  
Lest Bendwatcher’s eye re-ignite, and glaze the world with you.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "lead type in a composing stick". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Glimbertypes in Sticklequill

I  
Beware the Glimbertype, my son,  
That glints in glisk and gurgles grim;  
Avoid the Quibblestick's quick stun,  
For clanks will clink and typefaces swim.  
With slithery slug and clatterclack,  
The leaden lugs lie snickering slick;  
Beware the burble, watch the wrack,  
Where spindly sorts go snaggling thick!

II  
Take in thy hand the sticklequill,  
A lathy frame of limber brass;  
Set every maticule with will,  
Then lock the chase with creaking hasp.  
Lay in the slugs of silvern tin,  
Prime every groove with inky breath;  
Let swiveling spaces spin within,  
Till silence hums a hushed prelude to death.

III  
One groggy dawn he braced the stick,  
With tremulous grip aglint and grim;  
The Glimbertype rose snickering quick—  
Its jabberjaws in glisten hymn!  
Clatterclank! went quoins and wedges wide,  
As glyphs went writhing, waltzing wild;  
Each serif snapped like serpent tide,  
And punctu-puffs in punctum piled!

IV  
He jammed, he jabbed, he clenched the quoin;  
He clamped the jaws, he cranked the screw—  
A sudden snip! A silenced coin!  
The glimbertypes fell still and new.  
Return’d he to the galley shore,  
Where presses snort and rollers gleam;  
The proof was read, the ink ran more—  
The Glimbertype now but printer’s dream.

V  
Beware the Glimbertype, my son,  
That glints in glisk and gurgles grim;  
Avoid the Quibblestick's quick stun—  
Still clanks will clink and typefaces swim.

info.topic: lead type in a composing stick

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Urushilark and Rubern Quell

The urushilarks began to bark  
beneath the rubern quell—  
So hush, my heart, the nox will start  
its drip of dripper-dell.  

Beware the brindle brush, my child,  
its fumes of fimble-fair;  
Beware the gloop that gloams and piled  
a pox of purple air.  

He took his glimshing rod in hand,  
his gantlets ghosted green;  
He vowed the vile vermillion band  
would never blot the scene.  

Through gummer-gloam he grouched along  
the slickened slicker-slate;  
Each gurgled breath a bismuth song  
that synched with sullen fate.  

Then snappish-snarb from gnarry nook  
the urushilisk rose—  
Its thousand tongues in tincture took  
a tint of trembled snows.  

One crackling clang of curing cry,  
his rod rent ruby rain;  
The creature crooned a carmine sigh  
and curled to crust again.  

He lugged the lacquered husk aglow,  
through gummer-gloam withdrew;  
The urushilarks forgot their bark—  
the quell had quenched its hue.  

Oh hush, my heart!  The rubern quell  
now sleeps in dripper-dell—  
Yet hush… the brindle brush may swell…  
and dripper-dripper-dell…

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plum brown blueing bath". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Plum-Blueing Bath of Brumley Brow

Beware the brackish brindle-brew, my child,
Where plum meets brown in bubbled blues!
The taps drip drangle-drops, defiled—
Each splash a shade you never choose.

Take up your tawny tincture-tube, my bright,
And clasp the clinking color-claw;
The brine will shift from mauve to night—
Prepare for hues that haunch and gnaw.

So swish! The gurglegloom begins to rise,
A spraddle-spawn with slurping skin;
Its eyes are ink, its teeth are dyes—
It thirsts to tint your hidden kin.

You grabbed the gilded grappling-glass, you did,
And slapped the sludge with sterling stroke;
The creature cracked like crawlied kid—
The bathrobe rang as rivels broke.

Now hasten home through heather-hush, my heart,
Let no drip darken dwelling door;
The pigment-prowler’s pulled apart—
Yet stains still stalk the sudded shore.

Beware the brackish brindle-brew, my child,
Where plum meets brown in bubbled blues!
The taps drip drangle-drops, defiled—
Each splash a shade that waits for you.

poem:
**The Whistling Plaformoof**

Upon the gripple platformoof the stally shades convene,  
The clinkling clocks count grumbly chimes 'twixt twelve-and-twelve-between;  
Where pufflants heave and sighettes streak a singling slate-ash sheen,  
The farel-folk their vellums speak—farewells to leave unseen.

“Bewarn the Coilergast, my bairn, that twirls the trackside gloam!  
The scringes o’ the gateward’s keys! The shrill of whistling foam!  
Beware the Lurkle-bagman, and shun the huffish Locomosh!”  
He straps his cloak of goodbyes on, beneath the sobbrish awning-roof.

With tickled heart he stands apart, his ticket silver-sharp,  
He waits, he weighs, he wagers time—yet not one glance he drops;  
His riddled ring a tangled thing of lace and lore and larks,  
He boards with boards that board no more than shuttering of sparks.

He rails! The rail-roar rips the veil—the Coilergast unwinds!  
It shrieks, it speaks in boiler-cheek, a rune of rushing rind.  
He lifts his latch-case, clasps the clasp, and cries a cobalt cry—  
Then drives the dire deciset through valves of vaulted sky.

Back through the stally stillness creeps the shadow-shodden son,  
The clocks re-count the same amount, the same slate-gray has won.  
Come gripple to the platformoof—his cloak unclasped, undone—  
Upon the gripple platformoof his leaving lingers on.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ink brayer and chase". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Squinkerbray and Chase  

With bibble-ink at dusk they dabbed the gloam  
where gyreslip light on glumbrous chase did droop,  
each printer’s brayer, bruised of brass and chrome,  
lay hushed as mumble-metal made to stoip.  

“Beware the Squinkerbray, my press-born child!  
whose rollers ripple, purled with purple spit;  
beware its inkstump hammers, running wild,  
and clutch your galley-grams in grit-tight mitt!”  

He took a knurl-sharp spatula in grasp,  
hefting gumpled plates to guard his chest;  
he trundled up the chase with clacking clasp,  
and cranked the platen up for tense-set wrest.  

When whuffle-whirr came whurling through the smoke  
of linseed, lye, and leering night-soot scents,  
the Squinkerbray, all spool-tongued, sprawl and stroke,  
went glibber-glabbering across the vents.  

Snicker-snak!—the brayer spun a splay of ink;  
the chase-ring clanged, reversing roll-back spin;  
one splatter-splash befell the creature—chink!—  
and drooled dark doom down every dimpled skin.  

He slumped it, dripping, in a crimped-out heap,  
then bundled home beneath the moon’s pale paste.  
Come dawn, the damp rag-men made joyful peep:  
“O, frabjous smear! The beast befits the waste!”  

With bibble-ink at dusk we dab the gloam,  
a knittled story stinking fresh today;  
now every press-born whelp knows, safe and home,  
the Squinkerbray still skulks its own sweet way.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "summit prayer flag". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**Summit-Wuzzery of the Flags**

Up on the crest where the glumbrous haze
curls like the sigh of a tulp-sleep moon,
the skrimflay flaps in wiftish ways—
a prayer that shivers and prays too soon.

Beware, mirling traveler, the stronnagor’s tread,
shod sleeves of silver on talon slick!
it scents the folds of each red and thread,
gnashes faith-snips with its lig-nom click.

Pack ye the mirthmelt, the sorrowcar gum,
a virrifying vial to anoint the lip;
tie the doubt-flask to a frost-thrum drum,
and polish the blade named “whisper-grip”.

On the peak the stronnagor furls,
a thousand flanks in mirror ruffs;
it opens mouths like benedict whorls—
they rattle psalmlike in flag-tongue puffs.

The traiscant player lifts the hush,
a single hummly note awhile;
it cleaves the prayer from woven plush—
the flag-flap laughs with silver guile.

With spirals of vorpal-sheen, no less,
the whisper-grip glints, draws a sigh;
the tongue-blade dances, red to bless,
snips the strings—and off they fly!

Down through the fickle murmer-mist
where thaw-songs drizzle the gnat-branched vale,
he bears the flinder-knot in fist—
the stronnagor’s whisper takes to sail.

Up on the crest where the glumbrous haze
curls like the sigh of a tulp-sleep moon,
new skrimflays tingle in wiftish ways—
a prayer that shivers and prays too soon.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "luthier's soundpost setter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Luthier's Soundpost Sagger

I.
In slenderlain of sprucey waves where fiddlewoods unsprawl,  
Past frets of glowing amberhusk the rosets faintly sprawl,  
With pegbox dreams of cantorclefs and scrolls that loop & linger,  
The luthier vows, with sight unbowed, to set the soundpost’s finger.

II.
Beware the Thwingpang’s wincey twang, the tapper-gall who krites,  
The Briskneller who pops the shell and gloats upon its bites;  
He slings a million murtle notes into the hushy hole,  
Till timbers drone, their reeds out-grown, inside the trembling bowl.

III.
He selects the nano-crobbler’s tip, the drumblewitch-shaped pincer;  
He gowns his eyes in blinkers thrice, the better not to flinch, sir.  
Through stippled dusk the glue will work round f-holes jogging wide,  
Yet snibs of thrill await his will, the pin inside must glide.

IV.
He leans—when smooth as silversong the soundpost shimmy-slides:  
A clirp! A spronk! The box has clung, and sudden wonder resides.  
He plucks—then stops! for Glunkle tops the tremb’ling heart with dread:  
That sharpened leer, that screeching sheer, that dangles overhead.

V.
“Go glimmer in, thou darescrewin!” he hisses to the brace,  
It spirals down, a silver-thorn, to pin the Gremlin’s face;  
The Thwingpang squalls, its bristling calls spin emptiness away,  
The casket sighs; the luthier spies a poppied pearl of play.

VI.
He takes the fiddle, warm and shriven, from twisted twilight’s dome,  
Across maple strings it ripples, homeward glory to roam;  
Then halts behind the velvet-lined display of glowing flaw—  
Once more he hears, through quiet years, that first sylphinitic squaw:

VII.
In slenderlain of sprucey waves where fiddlewoods unsprawl,  
Past frets of glowing amberhusk the rosets faintly sprawl,  
With pegbox dreams of cantorclefs and scrolls that loop & linger,  
The luthier vows, with sight unbowed, to set the soundpost’s finger.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Cereus Vigil

The moonclocks clink, the starflints blink, the night begins to brood;
A shadow-bloom of cereus stirs within its hood.
“Beware the duskdrift, wanderling! The petal-blades that slice!
The pollen-wight that steals your sight in whirlpools spun of spice!”

He took the gloamglass in his grip, the ink of ebon ray,
And slung a shard of moonshard steel across the milky way;
He waited long with heart-thong strong beneath the tindled trees,
While nightmilk dripped from beak-lipped lips of whisper-owls in threes.

The cereus yawned with velvet jaws; the fragrance fumed and rolled;
It flung a coil of noisome oil that glimmered green and gold.
One! two! one! two! the pollen flew! The air went shrill with snow!
He sliced through scent with sable blade—one slash and spill of glow!

“And hast thou slain the duskdrift dream? The bloom that drinks the night?
O fragrant doom in fume-filled gloom—come home, my beamish knight!”
He danced through dew, the dreamdrift blew, the moonclocks clinked anew;
The shadow-bloom of cereus stirs within its hood.

poem:
“Rhizothrash of the Patchoroove”  

Beware the Rhizothrash, my patch!  
It tangles knobs with livid latch;  
Through blibber-ports the blurt-cords hiss—  
One twitch awakes the glitch-lit.  

He plastic-queued the noodle-knits,  
With blimfluff gauze of fibrous bits;  
He thumb-stroked pots in silent spell,  
Till squibs beneath the dials rose knell.  

Eeep—whorble—skree—!  The Rack got loud,  
Its sliders swayed like cacti-crowd;  
From mesh of scarlet solder-vine  
The Patchoroove disgorged its sign.  

Sponk! he jacked a sequenced blade,  
Of plated pulse the surge was made;  
In fractal jabs he carved the tune,  
Till half its cables fell marooned.  

Hooloop!—a hush—he trod the loam,  
Toward hearth of mirrored metronome;  
The jack-sheaves drizzled syrry-gray—  
“Home coils again,” the wizard say.  

Beware the Rhizothrash, my patch!

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Cassette-Wow and Flutter

The slithy spools did gimble round  
the deckle drail of drum;  
beware the Flutter’s wow-bound sound—  
the wow that makes you numb.  

Take hearken-hush and padless paws,  
and wind the warding reel;  
then crank the anticlock because  
the wow will make you feel.  

With whisp of hiss and spool-spin song,  
the Flutter skritches near;  
its wow-wail loops twelve seconds long,  
a wow that none can bear.  

Yet brave Bandersnatchian kid  
pressed PLAY and held it fast;  
with silver scraw and plastic lid,  
he wow-captured the blast.  

He snapped the wow with silence-seal,  
he flutter-flipped the tape;  
then spun the spool, and made it kneel—  
the wow could not escape.  

So homeward through the static night  
he carried flutter-cage;  
and now the village reels with light  
from every wow-cleared stage.  

O slithy spools still gimble round  
the ever-clean drumhead;  
no wow or flutter will be found—  
the kid rewound the dread.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "opal play‑of‑color flash". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Opaloch’s Chromic Clash

In glimmergrove where prismtrees sway,
And lucent leaves in lusters play,
Beware the Opaloch’s bright lash—
Its flash will flense your dreams to ash.

Take up the prismblade of yore,
Its facets forged on fabled shore;
With spectrumsteel and rainbowgrip,
Go questward where the colors slip.

Through iridescent underglow,
Past crystal cliffs of chalcedony snow,
The creature coils in prismatic light—
A writhing rainbow, fierce and bright.

Its scales are shards of shifting hue,
Its eyes are pools of peacock blue;
It breathes a blaze of argent fire,
A living gem of wild desire.

With chromacry and fervent cry,
You swing the blade, you do not shy;
The prismsteel sings through the air,
Severing light beyond compare.

The Opaloch gives one last gleam,
Then shatters into shattered dream;
You bear the fragments, softly glowing,
Back to the glimmergrove, bestowing.

In glimmergrove where prismtrees sway,
And lucent leaves in lusters play,
The shards still pulse with spectral flash—
A warning whispered, “Beware the lash.”

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "peony ants at dawn". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**'Ware the Bud-Kin Ants**

'Tis blithing at the peony's prime,  
the frabbling ants go gloam:  
They snish beneath the ruby rime,  
and plunder petals home.  

Bewarned, ye gard'ners of the day,  
with nectar on your shears—  
Their formlings file in unseen sway,  
and drink your roses' tears.  

Go swiften boots of hide and tin,  
and arm with crimson thread;  
Swing vorpal sacks of cinnamon  
to bind them to their bed.  

The sky-grow lightens, gold and soon—  
a hush upon the leaf—  
Then scritters sound the brink of noon,  
their mandibles bare, and brief.  

I stampled forth with crashing cry,  
my clava thwip did sing;  
I dreared their ranks with salt-crust fly—  
they shrilled like tin-capped ping.  

One lufting queen—she glint of jet—  
did rear her swelt crown high;  
I clenched and cast my snaggled net—  
"Back, brilax!" was my cry.  

She snappened, snarfered, jabbed then fled,  
her brood in dense retreat;  
Their spore-breath hot, my fingers red,  
my breath a battle-heat.  

And swift I hilted dawnbell bright,  
through sharded stalk I bound;  
May stalks again stand spike-straight light,  
may nectar nectar-found.  

'Tis blithing at the peony's prime,  
the frabbling ants are gone—  
Yet crouch they still in shadow-clime,  
to rise at blushing dawn.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "oscilloscope lissajous bloom". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Oscilloscope Lissajous Bloom  

I.  
Beware the flicker-whirl, my lads, the gyrascope’s keen glare!  
Its sweep-snake coils through cathode dusk, its trace-snaps slash the air.  
When volt-vines hiss in phosphor loops, the room begins to swell—  
For lissajous, the curlicued, will rouse its petal-bell.  

II.  
He took the probe of braided brass, the ground-clip, cold and keen;  
He wrapped his wrist with braided twist of shielding silver sheen;  
He tuned his mind to 60-hertz of humming homeward haste,  
And calibrated heartbeat to the sweep’s relentless pace.  

III.  
One tick-pulse into twilight’s grid, where ghost-glow wavelets glide,  
He met the bloom of lissajous—its petals opened wide.  
It thrummed a chord of color-code, it sang a spiral tune;  
Its stamen sparked, its stigma arced across the graticuled dune.  

IV.  
One slash—a clip!—a splintered blip!—the trace went clean and straight;  
The bloom recoiled, its petals coiled, its colors coagulate.  
He snipped the surge, he drained the verge, he quenched its surging hum;  
The dot collapsed to resting ash, the screen returned to numb.  

V.  
Return, return, oh flicker-whirl, thy gyrascope’s keen glare!  
No sweep-snake coils through cathode dusk, no trace-snaps slash the air.  
Yet lissajous, the curlicued, still dreams its petal-bloom—  
So calibrate thy heartbeat, lad, before the dusk resume.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "civet note and drydown". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Snifferclomp’s Civet-Scroll**

Bewarb, bewarb, the civet-note, so squiffish in its jar,  
That twirls through dusk and dawnsy dusk and clings where vellums are.  
The drydown drifts, the drydown drops, it gloams beneath the nose—  
Bewarb its purr, that velvet slur, that snares the scent-she knows.  

He took the amber atomer, the glassy globe he cranked;  
He twirled the twystle-stoppering with fingers faintly franked.  
He sniffled once, he sniffled twice, and felt the fumelet flit—  
Then corked the clockwork bottle back and tucked it in his kit.  

Out from the vat of vaporous dusk, the Snifferclomp arose,  
A patchouled puff with peppered paws and petals in its throes.  
Its tongue was tonka-tinctured, its tail a musky vine—  
It crooned a cloud of cumin-crust and clary-clove combine.  

One whiff, one whir, one waffling whirl, one whisk of whelming spice—  
He flung the flitch of flinty fume and pinned it in a trice.  
The creature coughed a cardamon chord, collapsed in cardamom snow.  
He bottled it in benzoin bliss; he let the leavings go.  

He trundled home through thistle-dusk, the atomer still hot—  
The civet curled within the glass, the drydown tied in knot.  
“Oh fragrant frabjous day!” he cried, and danced with dappled dray—  
For he had tamed the tonka-tide—and none could sniff away.  

Bewarb, bewarb, the civet-note; it squiffles still afar—  
That glimmers in the gloaming and gleams like bottled star.  
Yet drydown drifts, and drydown drops—it waits in amber gleam—  
So mind the musk, the murmured husk, that haunts the haunt of dream.

Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Regletree Bells
(a caution-chime in five quatrains)

I. Warning
Beware the regletree’s brassy tings,  
It murmurs 'long the furnitune wall;  
Its rivlets hiss in coil-trim rings,  
Its murmish shadow crooks the hall.  

II. Preparation  
She whetted her snipper-snoof so keen,  
She donned a galligaskin hood;  
She laced her glimber boots unseen,  
And stalked where timbers creaked of wood.  

III. Encounter  
The furnitune roared like chiffer-clocks,  
The reglet reared on jointed vine;  
Its eyes—twelve thimbles stuck in box—  
Glared green with turvy turpentine.  

IV. Decisive Act  
She clipped the creaking cranklescotch,  
She snipped the dangled gimbel-spring;  
The reglet fell with tinkley watch,  
Its furnit limbs collapsed in ring.  

V. Return (Ring)  
Back through the murmish, hushful hall,  
She tiptoed from the vanished wall;  
And now the reglet’s tings grow small—  
Beware them in the furnitune wall.

poem:
The Pitonscar’s Dirge

Beware the old piton scar, my lads,  
where crags go crickle-crackle!  
The slatewind snarls through splintered spads,  
and fissures fling their cackle.  

He packed a clinker-clanker cord,  
a cam of glimmer-gloam;  
he swaddled wrists in woven word  
and kissed the krinking foam.  

He scrabbled up the scritchstone throat,  
where moonmoss mutters low;  
the pitonscar, with ochre coat,  
began its baleful glow.  

It griptured out—a grisly gash,  
a jaw of jagged jet;  
its quartzish tongue, a lightning lash,  
went snicker-snack!—and met—  

His hammer, swung in hefted arc,  
a clang of clenched defiance;  
the spike sank home, a ringing spark,  
and sealed the scar’s reliance.  

He clambered down through creeping clove,  
through dusk’s dim dindle-drum;  
his heart still beat the boulder-rove,  
his lips still hummed the hum.  

Beware the old piton scar, my lads,  
where crags go crickle-crackle!  
The slatewind snarls through splintered spads,  
and fissures fling their cackle.

poem:
**The Loomwock's Shuttlepick**

Beware the loomwock's shuttlepick, my thread,
That clacks and flits through warp and weft of night!
The shed opens wide with clattering dread—
Its beak of bone snaps shut with threads pulled tight.

He took his spindlestaff in trembling hand:
Long time the slubbered doom he'd sought in vain—
Then rested he by the tenter's band,
And stood awhile in tensioned thought's domain.

And as in warpwise thought he stood, the loomwock
Came clattering through the twisted threadwork wood,
And clattered as it came! The shuttlepick
Went clickerclack through patterns understood.

One, two! One, two! Through warp and weft! The spindlestaff
Went snicker-snack! He left it dead, and with its thread
He went galumphing back. "And hast thou slain the loomwock?
Come to my arms, my beamish thread! O frabjous spread!"

Beware the loomwock's shuttlepick, my thread,
That clacks and flits through warp and weft of night!
The shed opens wide with clattering dread—
Its beak of bone snaps shut with threads pulled tight.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "tinsmith stake song". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Tinsmith-Stake Song**  

*Beware the clinkering clatterforge, my lad,*  
*And shun the spangle-mawed brightglint!*  
*For sparkspit spangles shift and slide*  
*Where solder-songs glint-flint.*  

*In tool-tanged twilight, take your tongs,*  
*Your flux-box, file, and mire-rod;*  
*Let rivet-riddles rinse your lungs—*  
*Strike tin, not troth, to fire-god.*  

*With blow-bright bellows, breathe the beat,*  
*And hinge your heart to hammer-hymn;*  
*Let drip-drop dross drink dusk’s defeat—*  
*So smith-song steels the brim.*  

*As coppercurdle clawed the crux,*  
*And pewterpeal prowled pale,*  
*He stoked the stake, he stalked the flux—*  
*The tinsmith, trim and frail.*  

*One! Two! And through and through*  
*The flame-snout flared and faltered!*  
*He left it dead, with tin-tarnished head—*  
*And the song-scorches halted.*  

*“And hast thou slain the clinkering forge?*  
*Come beam-broth to my breast, my boy!*  
*O frabjous tin! Callooh! Callay!”*  
*He chortled in his joy.*  

*Beware the clinkering clatterforge, my lad,*  
*And shun the spangle-mawed brightglint!*  
*For sparkspit spangles shift and slide*  
*Where solder-songs glint-flint.*

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blue hour on snow". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Snitherblown of Blue Hour**

Beware the Snitherblown, my child,  
That skims the dusklit snow!  
Its fangles frost the heart so wild—  
Its whispers sink you low.  

Take up the glimmerglim, young hart,  
And wrap in moonclove thread;  
For when the sky is torn apart,  
It wakes the not-quite-dead.  

Twas brisking in the bluemoor hush,  
Where silence cracks like glass—  
The Snitherblown began to rush  
With breath of brittle brass.  

Its eyes were lamps of lanterngloom,  
Its claws were crystal clocks;  
It danced through drifts of frozen bloom,  
And wore a cloak of fox.  

I waited in the shadow-sheen,  
My heart a thimble drum—  
I tasted iron, crisp and keen,  
And felt the blue hour come.  

With crackle-cry and shimmer-shout,  
It burst from out the white!  
I raised the glimmerglim, devout—  
And blazed the dark with light.  

The Snitherblown gave one last sigh,  
A sound like splintered song—  
Then folded back into the sky,  
Where silent stars belong.  

Return, return, and mind the tale:  
The dusk is never still.  
So guard your breath when snow grows pale—  
And blue invades the hill.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**Snorflittle's Croosty Rote**

In cross-tied croosty reek of sleam，
The whiffwold weaves its pitch-black gleam;
Beware the tar-king's carr-ooze steam,
For boogsuck hunkers by the beam.

Beware the clodge, the gobblegale,
The moke-slung drip in drood-silk drill;
Steep scalp and shoon in brief-shanked mail—
He scores the slope of Scree-clack Hill.

He took his vorpal jimber spade—
The one with conch-shell whiptag blade—
And honed the fringe with bodkin-staid,
While shamble spores in amber sprayed.

Uff, huff! The creocraw echoes far,
Through splinter-riven helpless ties;
The gunkSwarth rises, jelly-thar,
Prick-puffing seven vinegared sighs.

It wickericked!—a sludge-rid thing,
All bogsnout, blinkwuff, slab-wing slurry;
Its daulterclaws fret rivets, sing—
Its bibble cry a screech-musk flurry.

One, two! One, twain! O slitherslash!
The spade-bit sliced the glaum-grown coat;
Half-scorched, the brute spun thrice, then crash—
Its weepy lungs a tar-bird mote.

“It stankish stank!” he halfling crowed,
“Yet coil and gin have done their quell;
Now fetch fresh straw, lest lethe-cloud—
The whiffwold sucks the soul-smell swell.”

In cross-tied croosty reek of sleam,
The whiffwold weaves its pitch-black gleam;
Child, hug the rail—hug tight the dream—
Lest boogsuck twines you by the beam.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Collet of the Balanspring

In whirringtime when ticklets tockled,  
And balansprings in collets cockled,  
The horologer warned, “Beware the snatch!  
Lest cogwheels skip and hands unlatch!”  

He took the microdriver’s bit,  
And tweezed the hairspring’s trembling fit;  
He oiled the pivots, whispered low,  
“Return, return, or time will go.”  

The colletclaw, with clickle jaws,  
Came snipping through the ticktock laws;  
It snaggled, snagglier, snipper-snatch—  
A balance blur, a gearwheel scratch!  

One twist! Two clicks! The collet snapped!  
The spring recoiled, the ticklets clapped!  
He braced the bridge, he staked the stud,  
And stilled the whirr with measured thud.  

He carried back the colletclaw,  
Now tamed and seated, flawless, raw;  
He set the dial, wound the crown—  
The ticklets tockled soft, not down.  

In whirringtime when ticklets tockled,  
And balansprings in collets cockled,  
The horologer smiled, “Beware no more—  
The colletclaw is clipped, restored.”

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pantograph arcing blue". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Pantograph's Arcing Blue**

Beware the pantograph, my son!
The blue that bites, the arc that burns!
Beware the spindling gearwheel's run—
All whirring where the current turns!

He took his copper coil in hand,  
Long time the volt-storm foe he sought—  
Then rested by the tesla-tree,  
And stood awhile in circuit-thought.

And as in ohmic thought he stood,  
The pantograph, with sparks of blue,  
Came arcing through the galvan-wood,  
And crackled as it zapped right through!

One, two! One, two! Through air it spewed!  
The copper coil went whiplash-true!  
He left it dead, its blue subdued,  
And dragged it back as spark-drenched shoe.

"And hast thou felled the pantograph?  
Come to my arms, my ohmic boy!  
Oh frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"  
He chortled in his spark-filled joy.

Beware the pantograph, my son!  
The blue that bites, the arc that burns!  
Beware the spindling gearwheel's run—  
All whirring where the current turns!

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Murmeldread of Stubblefall**  

’Twas stubble-time, the slithy day,  
When horgles hushed the barley spray;  
All mimsy flung the reaper’s blade,  
And starlings swarmed in twilight shade.  

Beware the Murmeldread, my son!  
The wings that throng, the beaks that stun!  
Beware the churmle’s whirling cry,  
And shun the stubbous evening sky.  

He took his vorpal sling in hand,  
Long time the murm-chain’s path he scanned;  
Then rested by the thistle mound,  
And waited, still, without a sound.  

And as in murmish thought he stood,  
The Murmeldread, in starling-brood,  
Came whiffling through the dusky air,  
With churm and churn and everywhere!  

One, two! One, two! The sling went crack—  
The murm broke like a shadow’s back.  
He left it scattered, feather-fled,  
And shuffled home through twilight red.  

“And hast thou slain the Murmeldread?  
Come to my arms, my beamish lad!  
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”  
He chortled in his joy that day.  

’Twas stubble-time, the slithy day,  
When horgles hushed the barley spray;  
All mimsy flung the reaper’s blade—  
But now the sky was starless-made.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pewter inlay ribbon". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
PEWTER INLAY RIBBON

Beware the pewter inlay ribbon, shun the bray!
It slithers through the moon-glint, glimmer-bright;
The tinkers warn with spoons that quiver, stay
Beyond its coil; for dusk will smite the night.

He took his silver snippers, keen and keen—
A winder’s glove of flax, a spool of thread;
He stalked the ribbon’s gleam across the green,
Through clinker-hushes where the fireflies bled.

One, two! One, two! The snicker-snick came swift,
Through ribbon-rings the pewter screamed a tune;
The blade-edge kissed the metal in a rift,
And severed silver slumped beneath the moon.

“Has you the snood, my beamish blade?” he cried.
“O frabjous gleam! Calloo, callay!” they cheered.
He danced on clinkered grass, his arms flung wide,
While ribbon-shivers glimmered, sheared, and peered.

Beware the pewter inlay ribbon, shun the bray!
It slithers through the moon-glint, glimmer-bright;
The tinkers warn with spoons that quiver—play
But far from dusk, where gleams still smite the night.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "linocut brayer chatter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Linochurl's Brayer-Chatter  

1  
In the grooble of the ink-drowned gloam,  
the linochurl licks its litholips home;  
it brayers, it brayers, a clack-clatter of chrome,  
while the cuttle-craft crickets cry, “Beware, beware!”  

2  
Take the burin of braveheart, lad,  
the roller of resin and rag-wrapped stead;  
sharpen a sliver of lino, glad,  
for the linochurl’s blot-breath spreads.  

3  
He carved through the smudge-scrim with wristy swerve,  
he rolled out a reef of obsidian curve;  
he pressed with the press-pad—THUMP!—to nerve  
the linochurl’s chatter to hush.  

4  
One slurp! The ink-slick talon snip-snaps;  
two slurps! The sheet shudders in thunderclaps;  
three—silence—save for the pattering paps  
of ink-drops kissing the press.  

5  
He hoiks out the proof, triumphant and pale,  
the image uncaged from its inky jail;  
the linochurl slinks off, leaving a trail  
of cobalt crumbs in the dusk.  

6  
Back in the grooble of the ink-washed gloam,  
the linochurl licks its litholips home;  
it brayers no more—its brays are strome—  
and the cuttle-craft crickets cry, “Gone, all gone!”

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quarter‑sawn shimmer". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
“Quarter-Sawn Shimmer”

The glisterscope was quivering loud,  
the cypress heaves began to moan;  
a quarter-sawn shimmer’s slithrish crowd  
went flimmel-shivering over stone.  

“Beware the glowrillot, O wanderling—  
not half so docile as it sliyyes;  
with gliskered jaws that whettle-wring,  
and dewedle fangs no steel alloyes!  
Grip zwerchhilt, twist the tembre-trig,  
and off to bowlster longpron hide—  
but mark the shimmer’s slithrish brig,  
for dimmets drench the dusk inside.”  

He took the zwerchhilt tight in fist,  
he packed a phligalon of flame;  
with blueblade prancing he professt  
to face the gristle-clacking name.  
He sidled through the gladden grove,  
past root-lings where the umbren slept,  
till shimmer-grin he rimly rove—  
parched shimmer-grin he barely kept.  

One grinning glint! And lo! The flare  
(he felt the sky’slug croon above)  
hewed glowrillot from purpling air,  
its dewdles angling shred of love.  
Krackle-KRACK! the doomblade rang,  
clang-coballing clean clave sheen!  
Three shudder-thrums, then clang-bang—  
its dewdle shadows fell between.  

“Hast flornished he? Has dawning come?  
The shimmer-slink now rended, mute?”  
He bore the fangless luminum  
home wrapped in fogroot’s fusty fruit.  
Oft glisterscope is quivering still,  
the cypress heaves renewing moan;  
a quarter-sawn shimmer’s slithrish will  
goes flimmel-shivering over stone.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Tickwhirl's Tock**

Beware the blued screw's brumal gleam, my child,
That whispers in the movement's glimish core;
Its cobalt curves, in torque defiled,
Can loose the tickwhirl's thrumming roar.

Take up the microdriver's keen, keen bite,
And wind the mainspring's argent breath with care;
Let oil of moloch drip just right,
Where jeweled pallets freeze in stare.

Through gears it whirrs—the tickwhirl's sprung!
Its brassy coils in serpent-shivers writhe;
The balance wheel's wild song is sung,
As teeth in meshing malice scythe.

With one swift twist, the screw seats true—
A sigh of metal, hushed and prim;
The tickwhirl yields its snarling blue,
And time resumes its measured hymn.

Beware the blued screw's brumal gleam, my child,
That whispers in the movement's glimish core.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "parrel bead on a gaff". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Glimmer-Gaff Glade

Parrel bead on a gaff-rung, the twilight whirrs and hums,
Where slibble-slickle shivvers creep the spar in nightly thrums;
Beware the Gleamwing Gimbler, its eyes like molten crumbs—
It snaps the moonlit ratlin with clacking metal gums.

Young Tiddle took a brindle-rope, a pottle of pitch and tar,
A flint-spark snickering lantern and a whistle wrought of star;
He whispered to the spindrift, “I’ll tame whatever you are,”
And lashed the parrel bead along the gaff to travel far.

Through the grobble-gloom he clattered, past crooning coral rats,
Past wobblewings and murkled things that wore enamel spats;
The Gimbler dropped a shadow like a hundred velvet bats—
Its pinions clanged like wind-bells, its talons flicked like gnats.

Tiddle twirled the bead of brass, the gaff became a spear,
He feinted, flipped, and flicked it through the Gimbler’s crystal ear;
A shrizzle-shriek of ruptured gears, a shower of silver tear,
And down it crashed in tinkling shards, no longer wild or near.

Home he swung on moon-slick ropes, the bead still bright and warm,
The gaff-tip jewelled with victory, the rigging safe from harm;
“Come hark!” cried every sailor, “He’s kept us free from storm!”
Parrel bead on a gaff-rung, the twilight whirrs and hums.

poem:
**The Levainlurk’s Last Lament**

Beware the sourdough’s squirming spawn,  
The levainlurk that leers and loafs;  
It burbles near the bubbling brawn,  
Where blistered crusts and vapors hoaf.  

He took the vorpal kneading-nife,  
Through autolyse he softly slithered;  
All silent sat the starter-strife,  
Where sleepy gluten dreams had withered.  

One, two! One, two! Through stretch and fold,  
The lactic hiss of doom drew near—  
He twisted, tucked, then turned it bold,  
The swampy sponge shrank back in fear.  

“And hast thou faced the levainlurk?  
Come grip the grain, thou glut’nous boy!”  
He grinned a grin of darkened durk,  
And slashed the dough with savage joy.  

Beware the sourdough’s squirming spawn,  
Though hacked and heaved, its soul still sings—  
In crusty shards at rise of dawn,  
The levainlurk still loafs—and clings.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Sashikorith Patch

The boromorn hinkled sheer,
As flottid thimbles snarked the pleat,
A spangled gleam clattered near—
Borogritch boro marred the sheet.

“Beware the Sashikorith,” clacked,
“With flintler claws that clench and bind!
For scraps it snares the hapless dak  
And stitches souls to patchwork mind!

Threadsharp, my splinter, teazled tight,
With tharm and thiddle thorning taut;
Bindsole the mend, provoked the fight,”
His warbel whisper, wogging caught.

Boromorn again; the glinth reeled,
When sashikorith stoched the fold.
It slithred through the rifled field,
Its clinkstitched eyeswarms bleeding gold.

With one gilurkle surge he swung—
His thimblecross thwacked scarlet seam—
A horncringle sledged, sharp tongued hung,
Snipping sash from seam scream.

As nimlings forgled foreside ground,
The boronight bent pale and dim:
The patch prepared its spellbound round—  
Yet dawn leaked stares through threadglass trim.

The boromorn hinkled sheer,
As flontow leaves forgave the pleat,
Now peace-patched heart kissed fear—
Sashikorith silence stitched the sheet

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nixie tube warm glow". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Glowsnyt Vygerolmp**

Beware the Nixie tube's warm glow, my lads!  
It flickers, zaps in retro thrums—  
Through velvety dark its numbers glide, soft-glads,  
Entranced, entraps the slumb--ers.  

Beware the Wyrmzaps' coil-crack sneer, my dears!  
Sharp zig-zords arc from glassy throat—  
A vorpal fritzer! Clockwork tears, wet shears;  
It circles, buzz-king, cote to cote.  

With glow-gloved fists and mercury mittens worn,  
He fetched the Tungstine rake of song;  
He whistled zerflaps through the neon morn,  
Zizz-hissing tubes inside a throng.  

“Forth, glowseeker!” cried he, “to the luminal fray!  
Let our galliphants break the dusk—  
We’ll wring the wyrmzaps from their glassy sway  
And damp the glaze of mythic musk.”  

He tiptoed past the crawl-rack, hum-rack gloom,  
Past cathodeworms that click and gnaw—  
Till k-thunk!—a shoosh-wave filled the vacuum'd womb,  
Its gingerglass jaws a yawning maw.  

One, two! One, two! He prangs the glassy dome—  
Splintered, splendent, shiver-bright—  
A crimson fbwapp!—the digits yelp—  
Then mid-air spirals, pale yet light.  

He snapped the Zzzlant’s thalarm cord in twain,  
Caught ruby zero, coaxed its core;  
Wrapped sizzle-silk around the writhing rain—  
The glow-crowned head a limp encore.  

“Beknolled and done!” he sang, “the wrath is snuffed!  
Hoist high the nixie dome, pale-blue!  
O brandish orbs of amber—turned, rebuffed—  
Yet still they flicker: just for you!”  

Beware the Nixie tube’s warm glow, my lads!  
It murmurs, zaps in retro thrums—  
Its hex again the hallway stags, sad-glad,  
Entranced, reclaims the slumb--ers.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fishtail gouge sweep". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fishtail Gouge Sweep

Beware the gougesweep, my sprat!  
With whirlyflickered gillscrab tail;  
It friskers through the fathomfat,  
Where barnacles in silver-scales.  

Take up the snorkelsnout, O bold!  
The bubblescore of valvenhose;  
All flandlewhips and curdlecold,  
You splashward where the limpetdrowse.  

Clippettyclaw!—it loops and snaps,  
The gougesweep with prismgnashers;  
It flutes the waves in cobalt claps,  
A whirlcransh in coral-crashers.  

The flintbereft of razorglass  
You twist beneath its churnbelly;  
A swiftorsnap of kelpypass—  
The sweepbeast flinchbuck—shivered quelly!  

Snorfling home with fifs of cheer,  
The tail-divots gleam in gaspbright bloom;  
“Huzzah! The gougesleep lies sheer!”  
Dream snug, but...beware the next gloom.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "letter kept in a cedar box". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cedar-Box Epistle

Beware the cedar-box, my child,
Where whispers snick in scented gloom;
Its lock is wrought of winter wild,
Its hinges hum a thistle-tune.

Take up the quill of moonlit quince,
Ink it with dusk and dragon-dew;
Fold foresight thrice in silver since,
Seal with a sigh the shadow through.

He opened—snick!—the scented dark,
And out the letter-leeches flew;
They lisped of lorn and livid lark,
Of ink that bites the biter too.

With frumious flap the parchment rose,
A writhing word-winged wraith it grew;
He smote its throat of runic prose,
And whispered “Writhe no more—adieu!”

Back to the box the silence crept,
The cedar caught the scent of sun;
The hinges sighed, the lock then slept,
Beware the cedar-box, my son.

info.topic: letter kept in a cedar box

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "Morse straight key click". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Skrietch of the Clickwyrm

The Morse keys click, the static swirls,
The brassy clacks ring rithery;
All tempest-tongued, the ether twirls—
Beware the Skrietch, the jabbervy!

Code-boys in finger’ments of tin,
Their padlips glossed with tappersure,
They twist the freq and tune it in—
They skeg the band for clicks mature.

It sklooples through the ragmere dark,
It glints in quartz-lit monoscope;
Its nose is spark, its tail is arc,
Its ticktock tongue counts curt antlope.

One midnal, squall-bound, off the Bearth,
Young Tapper Tix leans dialward;
His morse-key raised like righteous berth,
He waits the Skrietch’s static chord.

It slibble-snacks across the band—
A smorcheon gnap of dots and dash.
With twin-dit dare and full-dash hand
Tix crops its clicker in a flash!

"Skrietchsquatch slain!" The ether brays;
The wavewinds swoon at zero beat;
Young Tix re-writes the legends' ways—
Now every set repeats his feat.

The Morse keys click, the static swirls,
The brassy clacks ring rithery;
Hero-etched in coilwind curls—
Tom-tap the Clickwhack snibbery!

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Frambilous Camberwough

Beware the plane-iron’s twist-whirr buzz—  
Its glimfer edge will skive your fuzz!  
Adjust the frog’s faint, squelching screw,  
Thring-whang! the camber waits for you.  

Fetch up your bevel, jaws a-slack,  
Set micro-maws to grind and back;  
With honing-stones in slipp’ring slide,  
Grisk whetted smiles the tongue once spied.  

Now brang the blade with liltling swipe,  
Through clouded boards of knottled stripe;  
The camberwough curls parings pale,  
Zith, zith, it croons its silver tale.  

One krench!—the mouth snaps open wide,  
The shaving thicks, no place to hide;  
O slishy curve, O glispering arc,  
It kiss-cuts grain and leaves its mark.  

Return from bench to measured light,  
Thumb-check the lip: still keen, still right;  
Again the chase begins anew—  
Beware the plane-iron’s twist-whirr buzz!

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
**The Orin Bell Hum**  

’Twas brimsy in the glistermorn, the slithy torms did spin,  
The borogroves were whiffling out their toves beneath the bin;  
Beware the Orin Bell Hum, my child, that murmurs in the gloam—  
It slinks through cracks of quietude and nests inside your dome.  

He took his vorpal thoughts in hand, his mind a sharpened blade,  
With cloak of calmliness he wrapped the doubts that never fade;  
He sought the Hum in echo-halls where whisper-walls are thin,  
And stalked the sound that slithers where the silent thoughts begin.  

Then came the Hum! A thrumbling tone, a buzz beneath the brain,  
It twirled through dreams and drummed on seams of sanity’s domain;  
One, two! One, two! He clapped the thought, he snuffed the wisping sound—  
He left it wrung in moonlight where its echo-dust lay drowned.  

“And hast thou slain the Orin Bell? The hum that haunts the hush?”  
“O child, I quelled its quivering tongue, its ever-quilted crush.”  
He wandered home through twilight’s hush, the air now still and numb—  
Yet somewhere soft, a susurrus... the faintest Orin Bell Hum.  

’Twas brimsy in the glistermorn, the slithy torms did spin,  
The borogroves still whiffling out their toves beneath the bin—  
Beware the Orin Bell Hum, my child, it murmurs still, though dumb...  
It waits in hush and hush again: the echo’s Orin Bell Hum.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Quenchingspurn of Brinewhiss Deep**

I.  
From brackish brogues of brinewhiss haze  
where clunking quavers swirl and roam,  
a squirming parch through saltspray strays—  
beware the Quenchingspurn, they moan.  

II.  
So slink ye hence with gurgletaps,  
for brine–baff vapors clog the lung;  
pack gloam-bottled whiff—no gaps—  
and mutter the curse the writhers sung.  

III.  
Through slubbrous gloom where twinged-tide taps  
I skritched, all tingle-teased and leer;  
the saltdrop sang its gritty raps,  
as Quenchingspurn lolloped near.  

IV.  
Snick–SNICK! I sliced the crustwrap tide,  
a plunging parched-jab pure and dire;  
the hiss—"prrsshh-khlup!"—sighed, denied, and died;  
the foam went mute with sullen fire.  

V.  
Back, back I crept o’er scritchling shale,  
with droughtless trophies, salt-blessed won;  
yet in my throat the brinewhiss frail  
whispers, "Still... still... the thirst is none."  

From brackish brogues of brinewhiss haze...

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "badger knot bloom". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Badgerknot Bloom Ballad

'Twas brindled dusk in Badgershire,
When nottlebloom began to swell,
Its frumpled pods a-grindle near
The rootlings of the Snackershell.

Bewharned, tsaid the Badgermum,
"Ye whickering brood, ye hushed beware!
That snordled Knot makes whumpers come
And snoggles through the muster-lair."

They took the tinting trowels seven,
With rakish yew and pricklerake,
To prink the dust and coax the haven
Where grumpling Bloom might uncoil wake.

Yet princh! a shribble pawed the loam,
Its gurn-rimmed eyes a-glisterin' gloam;
A warfling yorp gan howlsome roam
Through bluddle-dark where Bloom did home.

With twizzlepluck he clanged the clogs,
He brangled hard his thwisker-lance,
Thwap-thuddening through foggle-fogs
To brontle Bloom's mornth-fused expanse.

One snockle-flick—pinoverlap—
The snuzzer Bloom unwhorled away!
Its crimson nub split ker-chock! snap!
And sky spilled dawningerest pewter-flay.

"Come halfling home, thou braveling whelp,
The dawn knits up Badgershire's brow."
They clickled cups of dewdrop kelp—
And dusk 'twas brindled Badgershire now.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nib tine micro‑mesh". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Nib-Tine Micro-Mesh

Beware the nib-tine micro-mesh, the prickling squilligage!  
The ink it sips, the scripts it snips from every parchment page.  
With whirr of quill and clatter-clack it stalks each silent desk,  
And shreds the dreams of calligraphers who dared to take a risk.  

He took the flexi-pounce in hand—long days the wick-wand stayed—  
He honed the blade on stony suede, its edge like moonlight sprayed.  
With parchment-plate and gum-guard coat he braced against the shred;  
He waited, breath a silver thread, where foot-fall feared to tread.  

One splish! the nib-tine micro-mesh, through candle-shadows crept!  
It clicked, it slicked, it prismed quick—then suddenly, it leapt!  
The flexi-pounce, in lightning arc, struck back with serrated swoosh,  
The mesh went twang!—the fragments sang!—and silence shook the bush.  

He left it curled in crumpled swirls of ribboned violet ink;  
Its tiny gears now stilled, their fearsome tick no longer blink.  
Returning home at gloaming’s hush, he whispered low and fresh,  
“I’ve snipped the snout of that brute about—the nib-tine micro-mesh!”  

Beware the nib-tine micro-mesh, the prickling squilligage!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "krenovian plane throat". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Krenovian Plane Throat

Beware the whirling krenovian plane,  
Its throat a spiralling snarful drain;  
The gimlet winds in gurling skein  
Will snatch the wings from aeroplane.  

He took a spandled rivet-sword,  
He took a brass-bored rivet-board,  
He slung a thripple-throttled cord—  
“Come, krenovian!” he roared.  

The sky went skirling, slant, and sore;  
The zephyrs clanged their clanging door;  
He looped the loop, then looped once more—  
A skrawk!—a scrape!—a sudden roar!  

One, two!  One, two!  The rivet flashed,  
The krenovian’s gullet gnashed;  
The spandled blade through whirlwind lashed—  
The throat-gulf gulped, then gurgled, crashed.  

“Hast slain the krenovian plane throat whole?  
Come to my arms, my beamish soul!”  
He looped and landed on the knoll,  
His rivet humming, bright and whole.  

Beware the whirling krenovian plane,  
Its throat a spiralling snarful drain;  
The gimlet winds in gurling skein  
Still snatch the wings from aeroplane.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "rain on a tin roof". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**Snattleraps upon the Tin**

The snattleraps upon the tin,
A rucklerumble through the night,
The gutters glout with silver grin—
While shingles shimmer, slick and bright.

Beware the Dripslap Drench, my child!
The brolligush, the splash, the spray!
Beware the Roofle’s rivulet wild,
And shun the dankness of the day.

Take up your gumbrol coat of green,
Your slapsoak slippers fit for lakes,
Where cat-eyed puddles shift unseen,
And every drip a danger makes.

With flickerflap of gutterspout,
He slid in through the grattlepane—
The Dripslap Drench, all spined and stout,
With rain-slick whiskers, cold and vain.

“It’s thrumblthick!” the gutters groaned,
As shingles shivered in their rows.
The eaves began to bark and moan,
And window-sills were drenched in woes.

One drip! Two drip! He leapt the gap,
With slithersplash upon the sill—
My child took up their dripnet lap,
And drained the Drench with iron will.

“And hast thou slain the Dripslap Drench?
Come share my scarf, you soggy vet!
O frabjous day, the drip is denched!”
They gallumped home in rain-bright wet.

The snattleraps upon the tin,
A rucklerumble through the night—
The gutters glout with silver grin,
And slippers steam beside the light.

Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Senchabobble Wickernsqueak

Senchabobble wickernsqueak, the kyusu clinks and claps—
        O steamy-swirl the pinglebrew, the droplets dot and dart!
    The timble glaze with tansybreeze that whistles through the flaps;
        Beware the Crockleslurp, beware the wibble for your heart.

He flippied up the pottleblade, his whiskers flaked with brine,
        He flasked the lampish tinterscraps, he twiddled grip and band.
    The cantles glist as mistle drops go sprirring down the spine—
        He tamped the sippled garnish-plate with quiet quivered hand.

As crackle-gurgle gyred and gyre below the glassy glaze,
        Out spirped the Crockleslurp, all ogle-eyed and green!
    With snarkling tusks and coilinbreath it crooned a mistish maze—
        It huffled, puffled, sought the steamy soul that slipped unseen.

“Huzzarh!” he cried, “For picklyquest—no drip shall dodge me now!”
        He lunged and looped, the kyusu flipped, a spindled slash of tin!
    A spiral burble bursted forth—sssss—like silk spun from a prow,
        The Crockleslurp fizzdropped dead and oozed, all gone to drip within.

Rehoarsing roll-away he trod, the kettle on his shoulder,
        “So steamin’ slain the Crockleslurp—my kyusu keen and slick!”
    “Come hither, hither, taste the bliss,”—and granny clapped, all bolder—
        Senchabobble wickernsqueak, the sencha finishing quick.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Split-Grade Enlarger Burn

In twilight’s gloam the darkroom hums, the safelight’s crimson gleam,  
Its embered eye on trays that quake with sloshing Dektol’s stream;  
Beware the Split-Grade glare, my child, the burn that feasts on tone,  
Where contrast claws and shadows gape through silvered halide blown.  

He oils his tongs, he cocks his loupe, he calibrates the height,  
He slips the neg between the blades, a moon-masked shard of night;  
“Two filters I shall wield,” he vows, “a yin and yang of glass,  
To tame the beast of murk and blaze that prowls the paper’s pass.”  

A skrizzle-click, the enlarger wakes, its condenser lenses flare,  
A maddened beam of half-grades split spills zig-zag through the air;  
Out snarls the Enlarger Burn, a lith-masked, pixel-maned wight,  
With grain like fangs and burnished fangs like grain in over-bright!  

He dodges left, he burns the right, he dances on the clock,  
The timer’s tikkle-tockle beats the metronome of shock;  
He counts one-mississippi, two, the image sears to rust,  
Then plunges it beneath the tide of fixer’s silver dust.  

“And hast thou slain the Burn?” they cry, “Has contrast found its cage?”  
He lifts the dripping print aloft, triumphant on the stage;  
Its blacks are black, its whites are white, its mid-tones softly sing—  
In twilight’s gloam the darkroom hums; hush—hear the safelight ring.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiridashi scribe line". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**The Kiridashi's Scribe-Line**

Beware the kiridashi's edge, my son!
The whispered steel, the paper-thin bite!
Beware the scribe-line's gleam, and shun
The phantom cuts that vanish from sight!

Take pencil's breath and compass' eye,
Let T-square guard your trembling hand—
For when the kiridashi's shadow lies
Across your page, none understand

How paper drinks the bloodless wound,
How graphite ghosts through fibers creep.
The scribe-line sings without a sound—
A lullaby that murderers keep.

Through drafting-dim and blueprint-black
I wandered with my kiridashi blade;
Each slice a word I can't take back,
Each line a promise that I made.

The paper held its breath—then screamed!
(Though screaming paper makes no noise)
My kiridashi kissed and gleamed,
Cutting silence into boys

And girls and maps and morning light,
Till all the world was kiridashi-thin.
I signed my name in negative—
White wounds where dark should have been.

Returning home, I found my hand
Still held that paper-cutting knife.
The scribe-line followed through the land—
I'd carved my life into my life.

Beware the kiridashi's edge, my son!
The whispered steel, the paper-thin bite!
Though you may think the cutting done—
The kiridashi cuts what's right.
